div.p: A COMFORTABLE AND HEAVENLY INQVISITION: Not made by the vnmercifull Pope, Christs pretended Vicar: but by our mercifull God, in Christ, our assured louing father.
Or a Sermon preached at the Funeralls of the vertuous and religious Gentlewoman Mris. NEALE of Homersfield in Suffolke.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE SIR Edward Coke Knight, one of his Maiesties Honourable priuy Councellors Grace, Mercy, and Peace.
div.p:
RIght Honourable, this sermon being preached at the funerall of your louing, and religious Sister Mris. Neale, hath beene to me (as most children are to their parents) Both cause
of griefe, and cost: but in what manner I think not fitting to publish, let the world imagine it was by the dreadfull blasts of malediction, & enmity: for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , euill words wound deeper then sharpe swords, & are the cause of much contention: & albeit I can looke for no other but that perget maledicere, qui nunquam bene loqui didicit; he will not cease to speake euill who neuer learnt too speake well: yet in the midst of these blustring furies this is my comfort that many wise and learned fathers
(out of whose wels I haue drawne much for the furnishing of this little worke) haue in time past beene as little beholding to such as now I am; and therefore at length I haue learnt this wisdome that vituperari ab illaudato viro laudari est, it is the greatest praise to be dispraysed of an vnworthy man: so that the sole care I now take for my wandring orphane, is that he may by his trauell atteine that fauour to be receiued to your honours seruice, and I shall then assure my selfe that nec oleum,
nec operā perdidi, praying from my heart that he may do your honour that good seruice his place requires, to which end I cease not to pray to the Lord God that hee would preserue your honour vnblameable in your soule, and body vntill the day of his appearing.

closer.signed:
Your honours humbly
at command,
VALENTINE DAY.

div.p:
TO speake of all Gods benefits bestowed on our first parents, were to make too large a portall for this so small a building, it shall suffice therefore only to poynt out this one thing: that notwithstanding Gods manifold benefits, they sinned against God, and added this to their sinne that they fled from him, and God added this to his former mercy, that he made this inquisition after them, for he that keepeth Israell neither slumbreth nor sleepeth; his eye and his care was ouer
them in their profoundest sleep: Adam may flie into the land of forgetfulnesse, fall into the depth of dispaire, tyre himselfe in the wayes of wickednesse, as a man without strength, become free amongst the dead and exild from the law of the liuing: (for this was his estate) yet doth not God forsake him, but followeth after him drawing him to repentance, to make him an example of mercy to many babes yet vnborne. Of Iudgement therefore & mercy is our song; Iudgement in his flight, mercy in his retraight, Iudgement in his hiding of sinne, mercy in Gods vncouering of it; for man was falen into a sleepe (not that sweete sleepe of the body whereby hee is refreshed, but that of the soule) in sinne, which makes me quake to thinke of, and that also of soule, and body in eternall destruction
(which you cannot but tremble to heare of) had not God in mercy awaked him. O the height and depth of Gods mercy, who although he suffereth his children to fall, yet not to lie and die in sinne, as the wicked world doth: but suddenly striketh their harts with repentance not to be repented of, before they be cauterised through custome; as we see in a cloude of witnesses, as Dauid who when he had numbred the people his hart presently smote him, and in Ionas who when hee was fled from God, the windes sent as a pursiuant to fetch him back, who else would haue posted to hel, for he was well onward in his iourny hauing run to the hauen, paid his fare, entred the ship and slept securely in his sinne. Peter likewise thrust himselfe into euill company, for feare of a weake Damsell not only
denied, but with bitternesse forswore his master: but the crowing of the cock and the glance of his masters eye made him goe out and weepe bitterly. And Adam likewise receiued no lesse grace, for he had liked, lusted after, tasted the forbidden fruit, done his endeauour to couer himselfe with figg leaues, and his sinne with a silly and slender excuse: but God leaues him not so, but as a good shepheard seeing his lamb fallen into the mouth of the roring lion the Deuill, hasteth to help him, finding him out, vncouering his wounds, and pouring in the oyle of his mercy to heale his wounded soule. Seeing therefore that God makes such hast to call vs; let vs not be slow to answer, but with Samuell say; speake Lord for thy seruant heareth, let not Gods carefulnesse be a cause of our carlesnesse,
nor his watchfullnesse bringe vs into a slumber, looke not to haue the sonne goe backe or stay still expecting our repentance for the day passeth and the night commeth when no man can worke. The Greekes require earthly wisdome, and the Iewes a signe, but we preach Christ crucified, & woe to vs if that cannot conuert vs. I hope we looke not with Diues to haue one sent from the dead. If any such, I say not with Abraham you haue Moses and the Prophets, but with the Apostle, in these last dayes God hath sent his sonne to call vs to repentance. Oh how long hath hee called vs to awake out of the sleep of sin, assuring vs if wee repent our saluation is nearer then we thinke, if not our damnation nearer then wee feare. Wee read in the Canticles that our Sauiour standes knocking at his spouse dore while
the dew had bedewed his lockes; but she would not let him in: at length in her better cogitations she openeth the dore, and hee was gone: teaching vs that if we will not open the dore of our harts by the key of our repentance when hee knocks, the time shall come that wee shall seeke him, and hee will not be found.
Lamen. 1.12 Harke harke what a lamentable complaint our Sauiour made on the crosse for the hardnes of our harts. Haue yee no regard all yee that passe by, behould and see if euer you saw misery like my misery in the day of the visitation of the fearce wrath of God: as if he should say did you euer see such a woful spectacle, as one nailed hand and foote to the Crosse, his tender skul pierced with thornes, for the sinnes of others, as mine are? Yf you should see one iustly suffer such grieuous tortures,
you cannot but pitty him, but if vniustly and yet patiently, and willingly for the loue he beareth to others, not his friends, but enemies; this would stay you in your greatest speede. Wherefore though you be in the full pursuite of your sinne, behould this my loue with the eye of faith as you passe by and it will mollifie your hardest harts. But if you will not regarde it, I call heauen and earth to witnesse against you: for at this my passion the stones claue in sunder on the earth, and the sonne lost his light in the heauens: wherefore your harts be more hard then stones, and senslesse then the heauens, if you will not tremble and forsake your sinns. Thus doth Christ not with teares (as he called the Iewes) but with dropps of bloud seeke to mollifie our harts, least as wee came naked

into the world so wee should returne naked of the best riches. To day therefore if you will heare his voice harden not your harts to goe astray with the prodigall, and promise your selues quick returne: do not with greeuing, quenching, and checking the good spirit lose him by degrees and thinke to finde him on the sudden, for, When Mary lost Christ but a dayes iourney she was three daies finding of him, and shall we lose him thirty or forty yeares, and thinke to finde him in the last houre of our death? shall wee be going from a city a whole yeare, or more, and think to returne in a moment? surely this were to delude our selues. Well therefore, saith the good father, hee that promiseth saluation to the repentant, hath not promised repentance when thou wilt: lest therefore the sinne of
thy soule and the end of thy dayes make too neare a coniunction, and God leaue thee to thy selfe, so that thou depart with a burthen of sins vnrepented of; While it is to day heare his voice so louingly calling thee, for to morrow thou maist seeke it with teares, and not obtaine: to day, for this is the acceptable time, greiue not therefore the good spirit with cras, least your almost come to nothing: to day repent, for it is more dangerous to sleepe with one sinne, then an hundred Scorpions; for they can but kil the body, this both body and soule and cast into hell fire. To day therfore heare his voice, least to morrow hee say to you (as to his disciples in an other sence) henceforth sleepe and take your rest, for you shall be no more called for mee, and then good had it beene
for vs if we had neuer beene borne. Thus haue I (as loude as I could) sounded Gods trumpet in your eares, to awake you out of the dead sleepe of sinne, let him therefore that hath an eare, heare God calling vnto him where art thou.

Haec est vox interrogantis, increpantis, et commiserantis first by way of interrogation: looke how a louing father dwelling in a wood inhabited with beasts, if he misse his sonne, searcheth euery pitt, calling with a shrill voice, fearing least some noughty beast hath deuoured him: by which voice his childe (who was fallen into a sleepe) is awaked; euen so (me thinkes) I see with the eye of faith God calling man who was fallen into a dangerous sleepe in the wildernes of sin, where the roring lyon was ready (if God had not preuented) to haue
deuoured him, but God in mercy cals to awake him out of the dangerous sleepe of sinne. Was God ignorant where man was? noe but man was ignorant where himselfe was, for he had sinned and knew not, but fled from God, and had runne hedlong into the pitt of destruction (vndè non datur regressus) had not God in mercy stayd him and cald him back; man was become a wilde tree therfore God the good husband-man commeth with the sword of his word to cutt off his topp gallant and graft in a sien scilicet, a knowledge of his fault, that so hee might repent.

Secondlie, non tam interogantis quam increpantis vox est. It is by way of reprofe: for all Gods words before mans fall were commandatorie, and commendatory, approbationis, non exprobationis, but
man sliding God fell to chiding as in this manner: where art thou, what hast thou done? who toulde thee thou wast naked? hast thou eten the forbidden fruit? euery word as a seuerall sword to pierce their naked harts. Thus you see beloued that it is a fearfull thing to fall into the hands of the liuing God: Iudge therefore your selues that you bee not iudged of the lord, for though our sinnes be superannate, worne out of date, yet if they be vnrepented of, God will call them to mind with a witnesse, and set them in order against vs. There be foure sorts of men that get heauen, some by violence; such are they who suffer persecution for righteousnesse sake: others steale it (which is a holy theft) when by our praiers and almes done in secret, we show a liuely faith which is rewarded openly;
others purchase heauen, such are they who make them friends of their vnrighteous Mammon wherby they shall be receiued into euerlasting habitation; the last sort are they which are drawne by threatnings or punishments, and this is the worst way: for looke how the racke is to the body, to extort and wring a confession out of the offender, so is punishment to the soule of the sinner; for a wounded conscience who can beare. For although God when he hath drawne the sword, doth not throw a way the scabbard, as if he would neuer put it vp againe: though hee will not alway be chiding, yet if wee sinne he will chastize vs with the chastisements of men, hewing our harts and deuiding betweene the marrow and the bone, neuer ceasing to punish vntill he hath drawen vs to repentance,
and how much better it is to be drawne by gentle perswasions then by the rod, iudge ye.

Thirdly, non tam increpantis, quam commiserantis vox est, looke how a louing father pittying rebuketh and rebuking pittieth his son gone astray: so mee thinkes I see God rebuking man, in that hee would rather harken to the serpent his enemy, then to him his louing maker: but yet he pittieth him in that hee fell not like the Angells of malicious wickednesse, but of weaknesse. God had adorned man with all the heroicke vertues of the minde as iustice and mercy and such like, but man hauing sinned, they flew from him as not deigning to liue in so foule a cage, but flew backe to heauen, from whence they came, the one pleading for, and the other against man, iustice calling to
God for reuenge, that seeing man had sinned against an infinite God and that with an infinite wil (as you may easily perceiue in his flying from God and that he was so farre from confessing his sinne, that he iustified himselfe, and accused God to his face as the author of his sinne in giuing him the woman) seeing therefore he had sinned soe with an infinite will, he pleads against man, that according to his offence hee might infinitely be punished: but mercy pleads for man, that seeing he hath sinned of weaknesse, God would be pleased not to take his mercy cleane from him, but in iudgement to remember mercy wherby he might call him to repentance, and say peace to his soule. Thus God being solicited with sundry aduocates for and against man, hee calls to man to see what hee
could say for himselfe, that at least he might confesse against himselfe, and his iniquity might be forgiuen. Thus wee see abyssus abyssum innocat, the depth of our misery cald on the depth of Gods mercy, and the depth of his mercy cald on his wisdome & power: & so in mercy wisdome & power he hath wrought our redemption. Wee read of Dauid when he heard of the death of his son Absolon that he dyed in his sin, he bewailed him, saying, O Absolon, Absolon, O my sonne Absolon, would God I had died for thee my sonne, my sonne; here was a louing wish of a feeble father, but here (me thinkes) I heare a more louing and powerfull call: O Adam, Adam, O my sonne Adam, thou shalt not dye (if thou wilt repent) but liue, for I will dye for thee my son, my sonne, for though thy sinnes
make me to be spitted vppon, I will kisse thee with the kisses of my mouth; though my head be crowned with thornes, I will crowne thee with glorie; though my side be thrust thorow with a speare, yet will I show thee the loue I beare thee at my heart; and albeit thy sinnes crucifie mee to the death, yet if thou wilt repent, I will procure thee life. O heare this (yee sonnes of Adam) to reuiue your dying and languishing spirits, for though God be iustly displeased with our offences, his anger endureth but the twinckling of an eye, but his mercie for euer to them that repent; hee is a iust God, and punisheth to the third and fourth generation, them that with a stiffe necke in hatred and malice go on in sinning against him; but hee is a mercifull God, that shewes mercie to thousands
in them that loue him, and endeauour to keepe his commaundements. O turne you, turne you, why will you die? turne vnto God in sorrow, and contrition, that hee may turne vnto you in pittie and compassion, and heale your wounded consciences. This briefely of these words as they haue relation to God the maker of this inquisition, wherein he discouereth his anger to sinne, and his compassion to the sinners, in that they had sinned of weakenesse: now this inquisition is to bee considered as it hath relation to our estate which is fiue fould.

First, vbi Paradisi, secondly vbi tenebrarum, thirdly, vbi miseriae, fourthly, vbi foliorum, fiftly, vbi gratiae. First, vbi Paradisi, what estate art thou in in Paradice? In the creation God who delighted to see
all his creatures good, ioyed to see man happie, hee spake the word, and they were created, but to make man, hee seemes himselfe for to commaund, and cals a consultation that nothing might bee wanting to the perfecting so excellent a creature; he made him natures beauty, the forme of the creation, earths sole potentate, he infuseth a deuine Soule into a maiesticall body: and euerie soyle was not fit for man to dwell in, but hee must haue a Paradice, a place of pleasure, where the trembling trees bowed themselues in obedience, offering their fruites vnto him, the siluer streames ranne by, offering their continual seruice, and the maiesticall Lyon, with all other beastes subiected themselues more willingly than to Noah in the Arke. O foelix, O nimium foelix, bona si sua nosset, sed hinc illae lachrymae,
Man knew not when he was happy enough, it was not enough for him to bee Gods Vicegerent here on earth, but he seekes to be a God in knowledge: thus hee that desired to be more than a man, became a worme, and no man, in respect of that he was before; for he rebelling against God, all the creatures rebeld against him; the waters were ready to ouerwhelme him, as they did the whole World in the time of Noah; fire was readie to come downe from heauen, as to Sodome and Gomorra; the earth ready to swallow them, as Corath, Dathan, and Abiram; beasts ready to deuoure them, as they did the children which mocked Elisha; and the ayre readie to infect them with pestilence as in Dauids time. Thus man being in this great daunger in the midst of happinesse, God calls vnto man,
Where art thou? as if he should say, how was it possible that thou shouldst forget so soone him, that was so carefull of thy wel-fare? what blessing was there with which (through my fatherly affection) I did not endow thee; for as if too little to make the world for thee, I made thee sole Gouernour vnder mee, and set thee vpon a Throne farre excelling Salomons in glorie, from which (by ingratitude) thou hast cast downe thy selfe; so that albeit I neede not aske who was I, that thou wert so vnmindefull of me, (for thy conscience tells thee) yet I cannot but cry, what was man that I was so mindefull of him, seeing he so little regarded? surely, I begin to repent that euer I made thee, for by sinne thou hast disfranchized thy selfe of so ample amonarchy, and thrust thy selfe into a
dungeon. Beloued, if it were possible for a people to enioy a paradice on earth, we doe heere in this land, for we haue that happy Common-wealth the Psalmist speaks of, Our wiues are like the vine, our children like oliue branches round about our tables, our oxen strong to labour, our sheepe bring foorth thousands and ten thousands in our streets: and are not wee happy, that are in such a case, yea rather blessed in that wee haue the Lord for our God: For had not many Moseses beene instant in prayers for vs, we had perished (like the Israelites) with quailesin our mouths, so greeuously doe wee daily abuse the blessings of God. It is not long since the plague swept away whole housholds in our land, great inundations by water, and the earth denied her increase; so that many poore soules, hauing their children
hanging on their tender brests, had nothing but salt teares to releeue them. But (may some say) what is this to vs? Surely, a warning to teach, that vnlesse wee repent, wee shall all likewise perish, and bee brought from our greatest plenty to that want, that wee shall desire a cup of colde water to coole our tongues, and we shall not obtain it.

As this land is a modell of Paradice, so many (like Adam) are raised out of the dust, to be Gods vpon earth, like Moses and Dauid, from the sheephooke to the Scepter: or, as Saul, from seeking his fathers asses: or, like the Disciples, of fisher-men made fishers of men: I speake not this, as if all were raised out of the dunghill: for I know many are nobly descended, yet it was God which raised their ancestours, and who likewise hath furnished them
with girts which are not hereditary: Therfore Plato sayd well, that God mingled the complections of Princes with gold, of their helpers with siluer, and the Commons with brasse: shewing that God furnisheth men with gifts fitting for their places: and therfore to shew all foulemouthed Papists, (who raile against the supremacy of our King) that God hath giuen him power Ecclesiasticall as temporall, hee is so furnished with knowledge of Diuinity, that many Priests, both of the Papists and Protestants, who haue beene Proficients in serious studies, may notwithstanding learne of him. Seeing therefore that God thus bestoweth his gifts, that wee haue nothing that wee haue not receiued, let them that are exalted beware of pride, for if foelicitas superbiae, superbia infoelicitatis sit parens:
for superbus in solio est simia in tecto, in a fit place to breake his neck: and pride is the root of all euill, but vita ima, and sedes prima agree not; but verbum sapientibus satis est.

Secondly, vbi tenebrarum? in what estate of darknesse art thou? God made the Sunne to shine by day, and the Moone by night, and gaue his word to bee a light to their feet, and a lanthorne to their paths: but this is our condemnation, that wee loued darknesse better then light, and so gropt at noone-day, changing the estate of righteousnes for the poluted garment of sinne: And well may sinne be called darknesse: First, in regard of the author of it, the Prince of darknesse. Secondly, in that it brings vs to the darknesse of ignorance heere, and (if God in mercy preuent not) to that more then Aegyptian darknesse
heereafter. Our first parents being falne into this estate, God calls vnto them, to bring them to a sight of their sinne, that so they might repent, as if hee should thus expostulate with them; Was my burthen so heauy, and the yoake I layd on you so vneasie, that you could not longer beare it, but so soone cast it off? I did not cumber you with many commands, for at that time I needed not, you could enuy none, for none more happy then your selues, there were no virgins to rauish, no widowes to defloore, or wiues to defile, no Churches to rob by sacriledge, or brethren to bee opprest with vsury: In fine, I gaue you but one command, scilicet, to forbeare the fruit of one tree, and was this command so greeuous? had you not both store of fruit, for necessity and delight? did I not in a
manner make my selfe poore, to your store? see then how vngratefull thou art, and ingratum modo dixerim omnia, this fowle beast Ingratitude hath made a breach for all other sinnes: First, Beloued; our bodies are not so subiect to diseases, as our soules to sinnes, pride is the soules tympany, enuy the worme that gnaweth at the heart, wrath a pleurisie which will not be appeased without bloud, lust is the soules feauour: nay, whereas the body hath respit from sicknesse, the soule none from sinne, and all sicknesses haue their symptomes: yet wee so ignorant of sinne, that who knowes how oft hee offends; yea, many are so filthie, that you may trace them as a fox by his sent, yet they haue no feeling, oderunt peccare boni virtutis amore, as Seneca would not sinne, lest he should defile
so noble substance as the soule. And I read of Anselmus, that hee was wont to say, that if hee should see all punishments without sinne on one hand, and sinne without punishments on the other, hee would imbrace punishments, and forsake sinne: Surely, it was a most Christian-like resolution; for what wise man hauing a many Iewells in the raine, would not couer them with his cloake (though he be well drenched with the raine, or beaten with haile himselfe) to keepe them from rusting: and doe wee not see that sin is as a putrified flie to precious oyntment, or as rust and canker to the soule? for if thy soule be adorned with vertue, as great ones with iewels, one foule sinne raigning, takes away the lustre & beauty of them. How many men see we daily of good aspects, excellent
gifts, and comely personages, who by pride, selfe-conceiptednesse, drunkennesse, or such like vice, ouerthrow and staine all their other gifts, thus hatefull is sinne of it selfe: But Sinne and Punishments are twinnes, Sinne as the elder may feast it selfe within, but Punishment lieth at the doore, Idlenesse attended with the Scuruy, Drunkennesse with the Dropsie, Pride with Lunacy, and our first Parents affected knowledge with our ignorance, which how great a punishment it is, I appeale to any ingenious nature: who cannot, but to his endlesse greefe finde, that when he hath turned strength into weaknes, marrow into drinesse, and his colour into palenesse, by watchings and continued studies, at length hee attaineth hoc vnum scire, that he seeth no more then a prisoner at a creuice
in a dungeon, scilicet, that there is a Sunne which once enlightned him, which though hee cannot now enioy, yet hee hopeth one day againe to be comforted with the cleere shining beames thereof. But whither doth mine ignorance lead mee? I had almost forgot that the punishment of sinne was reserued for the next place: but seeing that I am entred into this subiect, I hope I shall not digresse in touching this part, so farre as it expresseth the miserable estate of sinne: examine therefore, and you shall see what a sympathy there is betweene the punishment of God appoynted for sinne, and the estate of sinne: For first, the earth (for sin) brings forth thornes, briers, and thistles; so our hearts being become earthly, bring forth the briers of sin, and not the wholesome fruit of righteousnesse, as you
may see in children and fooles, who will sooner learne to cry bald-pate, then to sing Hosanna; and well may sinne bee compared to thornes, in that it hath the same power to teare the conscience, as the other doth the garment. Secondly, as for sin, in sweat wee eat our bread; so in sweat we eat the stolne waters and bread of iniquity. Doth not the enuious man more vex his wretched soule at the prosperity of the righteous; then hee doth his righteous soule, at the sinnes of the wicked? Doth not the wrathfull man take more paines to execute his fury, then the patient man to put vp an iniury? I read of one, that being desirous to goe to Olympus, and being discouraged with the tediousnes of the iourney, hee was counselled by his friend, to goe so farre euery day that way, as hee vsed to
walke for his recreation, and at last he should ariue at his iournies end: So, if there be any (as I feare there be many) that would willingly goe to heauen, but that they see a Lyon in the way, and a Lyonesse in the path; I assure you (that if you would as much fight against and greeue your spirituall aduersaries, as you doe the good spirit of God, which sealeth your redemption) you should at last ariue at the hauen of blisse: for so painefull are the wayes of wickednesse, that that is most true of the sinner, which is sayd of the woman, that in sorrow hee shall bring forth: Thirdly, as the woman shall haue a desire to her husband, and hee shall haue the rule of her: euen so wee, to bee wedded to our fleshly bodies (for skin for skin and all that a man hath, he will giue for his life) yet hath our flesh rule
ouer vs, so that Paul himselfe could not but confesse, that hee had a law in his members, contrary to the law of God; For our spirits are like to a bird tied to a mill-stone, they may houer vp in heauenly cogitations; but soone againe are pulled downe with the masse of our fleshly corruption, as you may see in Peter, who was ready in spirit with his master to die, but presently hee did him fearefully denie: In a word, our corrupt nature is so filled with the worme-wood and gall of the bitternesse of sinne, that Nitimur in vetita cupimus{que} negata, the very forbidding of an euill is enough to make vs desire it; yea, with the spider, we sucke out poyson from the best flowers; from learning we gather pride; from courage, rashnes; from liberality, prodigality; yea, so are we naturally delighted in sin,
that we delight to see others sinne: not vnlike him, that standing on the shoare, or rather being tossed with the waues at sea, should delight to see another drowned before his eyes: for
Solamen miseris socios habuisse doloris
Sed miserum,— Like to him that ioyes to see his neighbours house fired, whereas he hath more cause to weepe, fearing that his will be the next. If this will not suffice to conuince thee from corruption, from thine own mouth I will condemne thee; for why hast thou consented with the body of this land, to make so many necessary penall statutes? it were cynicall to thinke to this end they were made, that great theeues might hang little ones; and it is the common folly, to compare them to spiders webs, wherin little flies are intangled, and
great ones breake thorow: for daily experience confuteth this errour. But if thou wilt looke into thine owne bosome, thou should soone finde out the cause, scilicet, thy natural corruption, for we are all naturally Atheists, ready to sin against God, the state, and nature. Hence proceede these heauen-threatning blasphemies, Church-deuouring sacriledges, vnmercifull extortions, and such like sinnes flowing from a corrupt fountaine: for though with Hazael, we thinke we could not commit such euills, vnlesse we were doggs; yet so dogged we are, that wee make no bones of them.

Hence let vs learne,
Vse. not to delight in the falls of our brethren, but to pity them, saying with that good Father, Ille hodiè, ego cras, hee hath falne to day, I may fall to morrow.
Secondly, let him that standeth, take heede hee fall not, for you see wee stand on slippery places: see how Esau hated Iacob, for getting from him his birth-right, how much more should wee hate sinne, which impouerisht all our ancestours. Thirdly, if at any time we doe sin, let vs comfort our selues in this, that wee haue an aduocate to the Father, Christ Iesus the righteous, hee is the propitiation for all our sinnes, for as the high Priest presented the names of the twelue Tribes on his brest-plate, so Christ the names of his Elect. So that, albeit with Ioseph, our garments bee rent by the temptation of our Mistresse and Dalilah, our flesh; and our body also cast after into the dungeon of the graue, yet (at last) shal we be brought forth to a Kingdom most glorious. Sweet Iesus bee to vs a Iesus, let thy patience
answer for our wrath; let thy mercy, for our vncharitablenesse; and thy righteousnesse, for our sin.

Thirdly, vbi miseriae? what estate of misery art in? as if he should say, hast thou so soone forgot that I forbad thee the eating of the tree of knowledge, sub poena, which (like the Law of the Medes & Persians) cannot bee reuoked. O miserable man, euill is thy estate, and better had it beene thou hadst neuer been, if thou wilt not now hearken vnto me, for in iudgement I will remember mercy, and the seede of the woman shall bruize the Serpents head: whereby, if thou wilt repent, thou shalt bee freed from the second death. See therfore thine own misery, & by these symptomes and shadowes of the other, learne to shun that great and intolerable paine; for hauing eaten the stolne bread of
sinne, thou must now haue sower sawce. The Poets doe faine of Prometheus, that hee stole fire from heauen, whence noua febrium terris incubuit cohors: By Prometheus is meant Adam, by fire his affected knowledge, for as fire enlightneth, heateth, and kindleth, so his knowledge enlightned him to see his nakednesse, heated him, that hee blushed for shame, and kindled Gods wrath against him: So that (like vnmercifull fire) in a moment it brought them from the height of happines to the extreamest misery. I may compare vs sinners to Iob, who was not onely tormented with botches, but his friends were miserable comforters, and euery messenger brought tydings of woe: this is our estate, our soules and bodies are defiled with the leprosie of sin, our breath stincks with the surphur
therof, our eares are deafe in hearing Gods word, our eyes bleared with ignorance, and our mouthes dumb to speake of Gods praise: Thus wee hauing metamorphosed our selues, we haue made God, of a louing father, an angry Iudge, our owne conscience mustreth vp accusing thoughts to torment vs, and the best comforts that are sent vnto vs, are mixt with sorrow: so that I may well compare vs sinners to a Traytour, who while he is plotting mischeefe against the state, hath his weapons taken from him by one, and arrested by another, and cast into a dungeon, and by his own guiltines being condemned, euery day expects the executioner: So wee, while either plotting the hurt of our brother, or how to sinne against our God, if wee would but looke vpon our selues, might see that our

weapons are taken away: for wheras God hath giuen to other creatures, weapons to defend and oppose; as to the Horse, the hoofe; the Bull, the horne; the Boare, a tuske; and the Lyon, the paw; man onely is naked, and yet he will not forbeare to plot mischeefe, which while hee is brewing, peraduenture a bryer catcheth holde of him, and teares him, as if content with nought but his bloud, and if they had tongues to speake, they would say, that God (in wrath) hath sent them armed with so many prickes, as sundry bills and staues, to arrest vs of treason, for sinning against God. But alas, our affected knowledge hath cast such a mist of ignorance before our eyes, that wee cannot see our misery, like foolish prisoners that know the Iudge is at hand, the witnesses ready, the
bill of inditement drawne, the executioner appoynted, and the place of torment certaine, yet doe they arme themselues to outface their misery: So we haue God our Iudge at hand, our consciences a hundred witnesses, the Diuell ready to torment, and all records sundry bills of indictment, to shew that we are vnthankfull to God, murtherers of our neighbours, enemies to our owne soules, and iniurious to nature: So that Imminet mors, iudicium, infernus, & omnia horrenda, & quasi nihil ad nos, ridemus, ludimus, peccata peccatis adi • cimus. But as they when death approacheth, quake and tremble: so doe wee, O mors, quàm amara memoria tua homini habenti solatium in hac vita? O death, how bitter is the remembrance of thee to a man whose comfort depends on this life? For
though thy estate is not like the Marchants, which hangs by cables, or rather in regard of his manifold dangers, by a twined thred; nor like the Vsurers, which is sure so long as the common Law lasts, if the debtour prooue not Bankrupt: but suppose thou wert like the rich man in the Gospell, that thou hadst not little but much goods, and that in possession, which is eleuen poynts of the Law, thou hast got it thou carest not how, and thou wilt bee sure to keepe it, let others haue watry eyes for wanting of it, yet thou wilt laugh in enioying of it, and so thou mayst haue goods, thou carest not for God: Imagin thou wert thus like the rich man, and wentst on as comically, what good would these goods doe thee, seeing thou must end tragically? for though he had gathered his crop, enlarged his
barnes, sung a Requiem to his soule, yet had he a turbulent catastrophe, hearing this dolefull ditty; O foole, this night shall thy soule be taken from thee: Thus you see our wisdome is but foolishnesse with God, for God walks opposite to the greatest man, if a great sinner. Thus am I brought into the large sea of misery: but if I should search into euery creeke and arme thereof, my life would not suffice, I will onely carry you from the land of security, and point vnto you the principall creeks, that so you might bee sea-sicke, and bee the more healthfull euer after: but seeing teares are the best Oratours to expresse misery; while you saile along, bewaile your sinnes, which are the cause of this your miserie in all ages and estates. As in our infancy wee come crawling into the world, and had wee so
much vnderstanding to see it, wee might perceiue our mothers halfe dead by giuing vs life, and had wee not the help of others, the houre of our birth would end our life; in our youth correction (which is as necessary as food) is a burthen and intolerable yoake: after, like vntamed heifers subiect to disordered passions; in olde age loathsome to our selues and others: these are the dayes wherein there is no pleasure, and as all ages, so all estates miserable; if rich, full of care, feare, and greefe; if of meane estate, subiect to discontent; and if poore, God help; for thou canst looke for little of vnmercifull man. Besides, the raw humours of the forbidden fruit are so vndigested, that notwithstanding all the help of nature and art, there are sundry diseases, which like vnto furies, destroy vs, before wee
can finde a remedy, some gnaw at the throat, others dart at the heart, others weigh downe the kidneyes, and racke the whole body: How many haue lost their liues with fetching in of Indian druggs? And others in searching out of the vertue of them? And notwithstanding their care and paine, we get that in a moment, which cannot be clawd off in our liues. Besides these diseases, all the creatures conspire against vs, for like to Acteons doggs, seeing vs metamorphosed, they furiously pursue vs, & as if this were not miserie enough, wee wadge warre one against another, so that man who was created a milde and louing creature is by sinne become lupus, imò daemon, for there is not the like disparitie betweene any creatures of the same species, as betweene man and man, as you may
see by our artilleries, roaring cannons, swords, guns, and pistolls; for notwithstanding God hath blest our land with a peaceable King, that delights not in shedding of bloud; yet twenty thousand pounds yeerely doth not suffice to strengthen our land against our enemies; and, as if it were not misery enough to haue enemies abroad, wee are enemies to our selues, our flesh fighting against the spirit, and which is more strange, our flesh fighting against it selfe: witnesse those iarres at bed, and discontents at boord, between man and wife: And, which is so vnnaturall a thing, as you shall not finde it amongst the bruitish beasts: many men lay violent hands vpon themselues, like bad tenants, so farre from paying of their rent, that they pull downe their Landlords houses, and as to the body,
so are not miseries wanting to the soule, as sundry passions; for by choler we attempt that which after destroyes vs, or brings perpetuall repentance: melancholy affrights vs sleeping, and torments vs waking; mirth incenseth vs to lust; loue is accompanied with iealousie, hope with feare, and our ioy ends in sorrow, teaching vs that our hearts being made for God alone, no earthly thing can content them, while they returne to God, from whom by sin they are gone astray. The Israelites before they came to the wildernesse of Sine, tasted of the bitter waters, lest they should be delighted in building of tabernacles there, and hinder their iourney to the promised land: so wee much more (while wee walke in this wildernesse of sinne) must eat with sweat, lest we neglect the manna for
our soules. To this end wee haue sundry afflictions, as so many little deaths to fit vs for eternall life: If yee therefore seeke happinesse, yee doe well; for thereunto yee are created: but ye must seeke it where it is to bee found, for resurrexit non est hic, heere in the midst of life you are in death; heere you must suffer with Christ, that after you may raigne with him; heere beare the crosse, that after yee may sit on the throne: thus like wise mariners, if wee sit at the end of the ship, wee may guide it to the hauen of blisse. Let vs therefore with the Doue, hauing a long time houered, & found no rest in this deluge, let vs (I say) returne to the Arke of the Church, where wee may haue rest for our soules, following this example wee haue before our eyes, which (mee thinkes) is a fit Commentary vpon
this Text, as wee may see by expostulating with this our sister, before wee take our last farewell of her: First, wert thou not happily descended of the same root, from whence sprung that honourable Branch, to whom the whole land shall stand for euer obliged, for his painefull and profitable expositions of our common lawes? hath not God blest thee with three husbands, by one of the which thou hadst issue, Mr. Mingy Counsellor of the Law, in whom thou liuest now, being dead? and now in thine olde age (though thou bee silent) the parish where thou didst liue will witnesse that thou hadst no churlish Nabal: But what meanes this still silence? Hearke, hearke, me thinkes I heare her say, Fui quod es, er is quod sum, I haue beene as able to speake as you, but now death hath sealed vp
my lips, but this is my comfort, that I did die daily, and as I often read of the Martyrs, so I goe reioycing to my graue, Non enim Deus deseruit, but hath made death a bridge for mee to passe ouer to a better life. Let vs therefore bewaile our owne misery in losing of her, for this congregation hath lost a principall member to accompany at prayer, hearing the Word and receiuing the Sacraments, the poore (which are many) hath lost money for their purses, meat for their bellies, & cloths for their backs: & I my selfe, all the encouragement I had in this place in the worke of my ministry: but whom wee haue lost, I am assured that the heauens haue found, and wee by following her good examples, may goe to her, she cannot come to vs.

Fourthly, vbi foliorum? what estate
art thou vnder the figg-leaues. You may read of a widow, which desiring to see better, had her eyes closed vp by a cunning Physician, who then stole away her treasure, which her eyes being open missing, complained that shee saw worse then euer: This was the estate of our first parents, for they had made a proposition, that it was better to hearken to Sathan, then God; that so they might see better, whereas indeede they saw themselues in a worse estate, and therefore sought to the figg-leaues for couers: God therefore seeing the euill euent makes an Assumpsit, by questioning with them, that so they might conclude against themselues, that they were auerted, and therefore might labour to be conuerted, as if in effect hee should thus say, Alas silly man, who hath blinded thee, or rather
bewitched thee, that thou thinkest to couer thy nakednesse by figleaues from my all-seeing eye? or whither fliest thou so fast from me, who am thy shield, thy buckler, thy defence, thy shepheard, thy God, thy father? O whither canst thou flie from my presence, If thou climbest to the heauens, there is my throne; if thou takest the wings of the morning, and fliest to the further most part of the earth, there is my foot-stoole; if thou diuest into the depth of the sea, there is my power; or if thou runnest headlong into hell, there shall I meet thee with my iudgement: So that if thou wouldst flie, thou couldst not; or if thou wert able to flie, it would not help thee, O hide not thy sinne, for in this thou canst not prosper; but acknowledge it, so shalt thou haue mercy, for with mee is plenteous redemption. Beloued, wee haue all
sinned with our first parents, none but Christ the immaculate Lamb can say, Who can rebuke me of sinne? Let vs therefore acknowledge our sinnes, and God is faithfull and iust to forgiue them, as if hee sayd, if thou hide thy sinnes God is faithful to punish them; but if thou confesse them, hee will forgiue them. O yee that are in the same estate of iniquity, beware of hiding your sinnes, which is done two wayes: First, by extenuating them: Secondly, by couering of them. 1. By extenuating, esteeming of drunkennesse, as good fellowship; and wantonnesse, but a tricke of youth; and pride, cleanlinesse; couetousnesse, good husbandry; ignorance, innocency; giddinesse, zeale; fury, manhood; oppression, the making of the most of ones owne; and vsury, a lawfull gaine: Thus Sathan
takes on him the shape of an Angell of light, and lest sinne should appeare in his likenesse, he cloths this fox in a sheeps skin. And so setting such a varnish on sinne, that it seemeth so pleasing, that wee can bee content to be trumpets of our own shame, with Absolon committing filthinesse in the sight of the Sunne. Secondly, wee hide sinne by couering of it: First, by attributing it to the euilnesse of the times: Such are like to Harpastes a blinde woman, who would not beleeue shee was blinde, but that all places were darke; so they, that the world is bad, and all are sinners, as they are: whereas, as much difference betweene the sinnes of others and theirs, as betweene light and darknesse; for the righteous cannot sin with that full consent, delight, and continuall practise, as they doe.
Others say of sin, as Peter of Christ, non noui, for indeede they are as free from it, as the sea of water: others with Dauid and Iuda can condemne sinne in their deerest friends, but not in themselues: others (like Thamar) muffle themselues, as if none saw them; or with Gehezi, say they walk not the paths of iniquity: but the spirit of the Lord is present euery where, vncouering and disclosing the secrets of of all hearts: to this end hath hee placed the conscience in the midst of the soule, as the Iudge of our actions, and hath giuen it a voyce to pursue vs, that therein God may bee iustified. I deny not but that there are sleeping and cauterized consciences which are seared, but they shall bee awaked: and (like a dogge) they will flie at the throat, and we shall say vnto them, as Ahab
to the Prophet, Hast thou found me, ô mine enemy? agree therefore with this aduersary in the way, for why should our tongues be loth to confesse that which our faces and other members acknowledge? For if thou beest accused of that particular euill thou neuer didst commit, the bloud comes into thy face, acknowledging thou hast the root of sinne, and so wedded vnto it, that there is no euill so great, but thou art prone to commit: and if any euill befall vs, wee strike our brests, as if there lay the cause, and if the punishment be great, wee teare our haire and massacre our flesh, as if wee would bee reuenged of our selues. Thus nature forceth vs to confesse in action, and shall not the word of God wring out a confession from our hearts? I haue read a fable which I will insert, to commend vnto you the
morall: the fable is, That one being at confession, the Diuell intruded himselfe, and being asked to what end he came; he answered, to make restitution. (I wish Vsurers, Extortioners, Church-robbers, and such like, would learne of their beloued Schoole-master this lesson) But what would hee restore? Shame, which hauing before stolne away, to make him shamelesse in sinning, hee had now brought againe, to make him ashamed to confesse. O let not Sathan so delude, let vs bee ashamed to sinne, in that God hath forbidden it; but not to acknowledge our sins, for God hath commanded it.

To conclude, the first degree of righteousnesse is, not to sinne; the second, to acknowledge and forsake our sinnes: wherefore, as by telling our dreame, it is a sure signe
wee are awaked: So a sorrowfull confession, that we are awaked out of the sleepe of sinne: Seeing therfore the night is past, let vs (by confession) assure our consciences, that wee haue put away the deedes of darknesse; which mercy God grant to euery one.

Lastly, vbi gratiae; see what need thou hast of grace; for euill is thy estate, and requires mercy, yet is not thy cause so bad, that thou shouldest despaire; for as in thee there is store of iniquity, so in mee there is much mercy, thy sinnes being a fit obiect for declaration of my mercy; for I will send my Son, the seede of the woman, to bruize the Serpents head. 1 Kin. 6. When the Prophets seruants helfe of iron was falne into the water, Elizeus tooke a peece of wood, and threw it in, and caused the iron to swim aboue
water, so that his man restored it to the owner, we are like iron, hardned in our sinnes; but Christ (by the power of his death on the crosse) hath raised vs from the whirlepoole of destruction, and holds vs vp by his grace, that after we haue swum a while in this sea of misery, wee may render our soules into the hands of God our right owner. Thus mercy hath life (as I may say) by our death in sinne, sinne being precedent in vs, Rom. 6. the act of mercy followes after, for by sinne came grace, 2 Esdr. 8.31.36. and because of sinners God shall be called mercifull; for in this Gods goodnesse shall bee praised, in that hee is mercifull to vs, who haue not the substance of good workes;
August. in Psal. 32. for the heauens needed not Gods mercy, because in them there is no misery: but the earth needed it, in that it is poluted with
mans sinne, and how much more doth our estate require it, who are a lump of sinne? but where the sin of man abounded, there Gods mercy much more abounded; for all things worke for the best to them which loue God, Etiam peccata Domine (as Augustine sweetly) for by sinne wee see our infirmities, which brings humility; for thereby wee are exalted to perfect rest and endlesse peace. Thus by grace are wee saued; for without it wee are wholly deficient, and that onely is sufficient for vs, both to mooue vs to serue God (for God hath sent his spirit to worke grace in our hearts, Tit. teaching vs to deny all vngodlinesse and worldly lusts, to walke righteously and soberly in this present worldly) And likewise, that soly mooueth God to salue vs: Fulgentiu. so that, Datur ex gratia non solùm iustificatis vita bona, sed glorificatis
vita aeterna: The first you may see in Peter, who was vas gratiae; for when, as by lamentable experience, hee had found that hee had not strength sufficient in himselfe, to keepe him from denying his Lord, & Master, but presuming that hee was strong enough to encounter the whole world, he found himselfe too weake to withstand a silly Damosell, by this hee learnt wholly to deny himselfe and his owne strength; for being thrice asked after, If hee loued Christ, hee answered, thou knowest, as (if he should say) I haue no power, but that is giuen from thee, and how long it will bee continued, it is best knowen to thee, and thou no sooner takes this grace from me, but I fall from thee, so that in me there is neither strength nor knowledge of louing thee. O yee that boast so
much of your succession from Peter, if you bee his successours, make it knowen by doing his workes, scilicet, by denying your owne merits, and establishing Gods grace; trust not to your owne strength, for (like a broken reede) it is already run into your flesh, as you may see (by your great polutions) which haue been in your holiest places; but rely wholly on Gods grace, for sufficit gratia, like the widowes oile, lasting all the time of the famin, euen so long as we hunger & thirst after righteousnesse, vntill wee shall bee satisfied in glory; for although such is our frailty, we are vnable to serue God, yet hath grace wrought a will in vs, and God for Christs sake accepts our wills and endeauours, supplyeth our spirituall wants, and pardoneth our defects, Omnia igitur mandata adimplentur cum quicquid
non fit ignoscitur: for our righteousnesse consists of remission of sinnes, not perfection of vertues, that man onely being blessed, to whom the Lord imputeth no sinne, for if God entreth into iudgement, no flesh shall be iustified; all the righteousnes of man being as a stained cloth: So that our good works cannot be iustified before God for their worth: how far are those works then, from making satisfaction for our sins, which are not of God required, but fetched out of our owne braine (as hearing of masses, going on pilgrimage, wearing haire-cloth, making of vowes, whipping themselues, with such like, opera supererogationis, superfluous workes, which God neuer commanded: and therefore are false coyne, deseruing death for minting it, and shall neuer be taken for payment of Gods all-seeing eye)
for wee are dead in Adam, so that our best thoughts are meere mischeefe and malice against God, Gal. 2 10. 1 Cor. 8.46. and when we haue done all we can, wee are vnprofitable seruants. All our imaginations & thoughts are continually euill, Gen. 6.5. Eph. 2 1. • oh. 15.5. • . Cor. 3. wee are dead in sinne, and can doe no good, no not thinke a good thought, so that Augustine saith well,

that she is beholding to him for his grace, shee will satisfie in part for originall sinne, saying, Although the merits of Christ are the most speciall desert, thorow which Gods mercy, and the way vnto the Kingdome of heauen is granted vnto vs, yet this notwithstanding is in no wise to bee reckoned, for the onely whole and full satisfaction: And therefore for the satisfying for originall sinne, they adioyned the merits of the Sacrament of Baptisme, which giue vnto men mercy, ex opere operato, and to say all in a word, that wee must satisfie for all sinnes, and stand in no neede of grace. For they magnifie our pure Naturals, as able to performe good workes congruously meritorious; saying, that Voluntas est absolutè & simpliciter actiua: but thus doing,
they doe not imitate him, which threw away his cloake to goe to Christ; but the childe Samuel, who being called of God, ranne to Eli. But their manifold fals are sufficient to confute them, and there is no more to be sayd, but all are debtors to God, and stand in neede both of supporting and directing grace; for heere wee are ignorant trauellers, and want a guide to vs, Nudos nos in fide prima gratia genuit, & in assumptione nudos eadem saluabit;
•… oh. 8.1. I (saith Christ) am the light of the world, hee that followes mee shall not walke in darknesse, but shall haue the light of life: So that wee sitting in darknesse, hee comes like a good friend to enlighten vs;
•… oh. 8.51.47. Verily, if any keepe my word, hee shall not see death. Now what is it to keepe his word, but to beleeue the word of his Gospell? In a word, what is the whole
word, but tuba gratiae, a trumpet of grace, sounding in our eares this sweet ditty; that, as by one Adam all die, so by Christ all are restored to life, Rom. 7.2. O miserable man (saith Paul) who shall deliuer me from this body of death: Thankes be to God thorow Christ, as if he should say, why stand I staring on mine owne vnworthinesse, seeing it is Christs merit, which must giue entrance vnto the presence of God, Qualecun{que} sit ergo peccatum, of what high nature soeuer therefore thy sinne bee (if thou wilt repent) God will pardon it. Esa. 65.7. Beware therefore, that by desperation, thou shut not his hands, adde not this to thy former sinne, but forsake thy euill way, and returne vnto the Lord, and hee will haue mercy on thee, for hee is multus ad ignoscendum, very ready to forgiue: comfort then thy selfe with this in thy
strongest temptation, oppose against Sathan Christ who is stronger; and against our weaknesse, his grace; against our sinne, his righteousnesse; against death, his resurrection, who is the first fruits of the resurrection; and against hels torture, heauens glory: Let vs wholly distrust in our selues, and trust in him; for he is our Preist, Sacrifice, Light, Sauiour, Reconciliation, Propitiation, Oblation, Sanctification, Iustification, and Glorification: O Lamb of God, that takest away the sinnes of the world, haue mercy vpon vs; and so guide vs heere with thy grace, that wee may dwell with thee for euer in glory. Amen.
